results.title: The Lost weekend
results.creator_credit: Charles Brackett, Paramount Pictures and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: This classic Hollywood drama scooped the Oscars in 1945 and it is not surprising. Ray Milland is an alcoholic writer who cannot control his binge drinking. Over a torturous weekend we see how the lure of alcohol has destroyed his confidence, his self-respect and his ambition. As it threatens to eat away at his talent, he comes closer and closer to suicidal despair. From a contemporary perspective the moralistic ending may appear trite but what is undeniable is Billy Wilder’s talent at creating a film which seems to visually simulate the terrifying perspective of a drug user’s imagination. Milland too is excellent as a man who is unable to reach the goals he sets himself. As a study of writer’s block, “The Lost Weekend” is both perceptive and illuminating. Jane Wyman appears as his long-suffering lover, however the book’s original narrative linked the writer’s fear of failure to his ambiguous sexuality. An outstanding film. Based on the book by Charles Jackson.

results.title: The Lost wax method of bronze casting
results.creator_credit: Fotosonic, Harmon Foundation and Leo Steiner
results.brief_description: Vincent Kofi, a Ghanian sculptor, is shown making a bronze casting of his “Awakening Africa” using the lost wax method. The process - from modelling the original clay figurine to the finished work on the metal casting - is shown.

results.title: The Lost waters of the Nile
results.creator_credit: Alec Nisbett, KRO-TV Hilversum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Report on the issues surrounding the construction of the Jonglei Canal, a massive engineering project intended to bypass an enormous area of marshland formed by the waters of the White Nile. Considers in particular the effects on the Dinka people who inhabit the area and the difficulties facing the builders of the canal.

results.title: The Lost tribe
results.creator_credit: Meridian Films, New Zealand Film Commission, Gary Hannam and John Laing
results.brief_description: In this suspense thriller, a missing anthropologist is given up for lost by his wife (Darien Takle) and twin brother Edward (John Bach), but his daughter (Emma Takle) is convinced something odd is involved in her father’s disappearance. Events conspire to put the three people together on a manhunt for the anthropologist amongst a “lost” tribe in the dense jungle of the southern island of New Zealand.

results.title: The Lost time capsule
results.creator_credit: Heather Ogilvie, Look At It My Way Films, Australian Bicentennial Authority and Geoffrey Bennett
results.brief_description: In the year 2088 a group of children discover a time capsule from the Bicentenary year. When opened it shows a short, musical, promotional film with the theme “Living together always”, highlighting the multicultural nature of Australian society, the outdoor life, brief film excerpts from Australia’s modern history, culminating in the creation of a mural by schoolchildren.

results.title: The Lost pharaoh: the search for Akhenaten
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Nicholas Kendall
results.brief_description: The fascinating story of an ancient Pharaoh and the archaeological sleuthing which went into piecing together information about his life. An accidental discovery in 1975 by Canadian archaeologist Dr. Donald Redford and his team led to the uncovering of the foundation of one of Akhenaten’s temples. Commentary and narration by Donald Brittain.

results.title: The Lost James Brown tapes
results.creator_credit: Gravity, Chris Mould and Alan Douglas
results.brief_description: Exciting live concert footage of the master of funk and godfather of soul, the inimitable James Brown. Supposedly shot in Monterey, California in 1979, this live concert shows the master in fine form. His powerful voice and trademark dance moves don’t disappoint but the transition to DVD format is a little dubious (may have been shot off a television screen). The ten songs featured are: “Get up offa that thing”, “Body heat”, “Try me”, “Sex machine”, “Georgia on my mind”, “Please please please”, “Hindsight”, “Can’t stand it”, “Papa’s got a brand new bag” and “Jam”. Original producers of the live concert footage were Eric Therman, Rod Crowe and Robert Sheridan. The title listed on the cover (as opposed to the actual work) is “James Brown: Body Heat Live”.

results.title: The Lost generation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
Keith Windschuttle, looks at the problems of high youth unemployment as manifested in the increasing numbers of young homeless people squatting in derelict houses. Suggests that more innovations in secondary education would help prepare students for the realities of the present job market.

results.title: The Lost boys (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Harvey Bernhard, Warner Bros Pictures and Joel Schumacher
results.brief_description: This popular 1987 film presents an interesting mix of genres: the 1980s teen movie with vampires. Michael and Sam are two brothers who have moved with their mother to Santa Carla, “murder capitol of the world”, unaware of the vampires residing in this fictional Californian Coastal town (the film was shot in Santa Barbara, and includes spectacular footage of the Boardwalk and beach-side amusement park). Michael is charmed by a girl named Star, and immediately falls in with a tough young gang led by David. It’s peer pressure in the extreme as Michael is tricked into drinking blood. He is turned into an unwilling vampire, and Sam looks to a pair of comic book vendors who are well versed in the dealings with vampires, to help save Michael. The insecurities and frustrations of youth are amplified and satirised by this exciting and funny MTV-generation thriller. Cast includes: Jason Patric, Corey Haim, Dianne Wiest, Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman.

results.creator_credit: Harvey Bernhard, Warner Bros Pictures and Joel Schumacher
results.brief_description: This popular 1987 film presents an interesting mix of genres: the 1980s teen movie with vampires. Michael and Sam are two brothers who have moved with their mother to Santa Carla, “murder capitol of the world”, unaware of the vampires residing in this fictional Californian Coastal town (the film was shot in Santa Barbara, and includes spectacular footage of the Boardwalk and beach-side amusement park). Michael is charmed by a girl named Star (Jamie Gertz), and immediately falls in with a tough young gang led by David. It’s peer pressure in the extreme as Michael is tricked into drinking blood. He is turned into an unwilling vampire, and Sam looks to a pair of comic book vendors who are well versed in the dealings with vampires, to help save Michael. The insecurities and frustrations of youth are amplified and satirised by this exciting and funny MTV-generation thriller. Cast includes: Jason Patric, Corey Haim, Dianne Wiest, Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman.
